Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Effective Field Theories from String Compactification
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Jonathan Heckman at the University of North Carolina (UNC)at Chapel Hill. This research will focus on using string theory to understand the workings of Nature at the shortest distance scales. Strings continue to have significant impact on theoretical physics, with interdisciplinary connections ranging from the physics of subatomic particles to pure mathematics. One of the most important open issues is how to connect this framework to experimentally verified theories of subatomic particles. This project aims to use the geometry of extra dimensions predicted by string theory to construct and study theoretical models of relevance both for theories of subatomic particles, and for more formal mathematical applications.

The education and outreach efforts of this program will introduce students to the power of geometric methods in theoretical physics. 1) At the postdoc and graduate level, the PI will maintain a collaborative research environment. 2) The PI will develop a course on geometric methods in high energy theory. 3) At the undergraduate level, the PI will advise students on geometric and computational aspects of string theory through the UNC REU program on computational methods in physics held in his department. 4) The PI will work closely with the Morehead Planetarium and Science Center to develop a set of outreach modules aimed at conveying the broad range of energy scales which are actively being investigated by high energy theorists and experimentalists.

The technical components of this program will focus on the development of new tools in the study of string compactification at strong coupling, and the resulting low energy effective field theories. Particular emphasis will be placed on compactifications of F-theory. This will entail developing the correspondence between the open string degrees of freedom in the worldvolume theory of intersecting seven-branes, and closed string degrees of freedom captured by elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau manifolds. Additional components will entail the development of specific string-motivated scenarios for physics beyond the Standard Models of particle physics and cosmology. Particle physics applications will include the study of kinetic mixing with a strongly coupled extra sector. Cosmology applications will include the development of inflationary reheating scenarios coupled to concrete stringy particle physics models. This project will also focus on using the geometry of F-theory compactifications as a tool to classify and study superconformal field theories (SCFTs) in diverse dimensions. This will include a classification of 6D SCFTs, the construction of new 4D N = 1 SCFTs from D3-brane probes of singular Calabi-Yau fourfold geometries, and the development of 2D SCFTs with N = (0,2) supersymmetry from compactification on singular elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau fivefolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes from the NSF Grant CAREER: Effective Field Theories from String Compactification was centered on topics connected with high energy physics. This is the branch of physics aimed at understanding Nature at the smallest distance scales, and the potential impact of these physical structures on phenomena at much larger scales. The research of this project was conducted at UNC Chapel Hill in the first two years of the project and at the University of Pennsylvania in the last three years of the project.

The particular intellectual components of this work involved using the small additional spatial dimensions predicted by string theory as a tool in understanding the possible ways in which observable long distance phenomena could emerge. At long distances, the framework for forging such connections is known as “effective field theory.” The primary aim of the project was to determine the range of possible effective field theories which can be realized in string theory, both as a way of testing this general framework, and also as a way to develop new scenarios for the physics of subatomic particles. A particularly prominent role in the project centered on the geometric realization of a special class of effective field theories known as “conformal field theories.” These are theories in which there are no length or mass scales, and as such are somewhat simpler to study using a variety of techniques. Specific noteworthy results included the classification and study of many such theories using techniques from geometry. In particular, this project has greatly elucidated the structure of conformal field theories in more than four spacetime dimensions. These particular theories are of particular significance because they also provide insight into physical systems in four and fewer spacetime dimensions. Another key component in this work centered on the development of entirely new scenarios based on the extra dimensions of string theory and how they could descend to observable phenomena. This included the development of new scenarios for how subatomic particles could be detected at particle accelerators, in ongoing searches for dark matter, as well as in the development of new cosmological scenarios aimed at understanding the expansion in the size of the Universe. Additional outcomes from this work included applications to closely related areas of mathematics, where methods from physics were used to make predictions on new sorts of mathematical structures associated with the geometry of extra dimensions.

The broader impacts of this project centered on explaining to a broader audience some of the exciting recent developments in understanding Nature at small distance scales. A particular emphasis was placed on visits to local schools and public speaking venues, where outreach materials were developed to facilitate a “hands-on” approach to this abstract material. This included outreach modules on specific topics in subatomic particles including the physics of neutrinos as well as the Higgs boson. In addition to these in person presentations, a number of online resources were developed including a YouTube channel and website specifically developed to elucidate a number of facets connected with the physics of subatomic particles and the quest for a unified understanding of Nature at the smallest distance scales.
